required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Calcineurin Inhibitor Sparing After Kidney Transplantation
clinical_study.official_title: Calcineurin-Sparing in a Steroid-free Maintenance Immunosuppression Protocol After Kidney Transplantation

collaborator.agency: Wyeth is now a wholly owned subsidiary of Pfizer

brief_summary.textblock: Reducing drug side effects is a key issue in transplantation. One class of drugs commonly used, calcineurin inhibitors (CNIs), is associated with negative side effects, namely, toxicity to the transplanted kidney. In some patients, this toxicity is thought to be associated with loss of transplant function in those who have had their transplants for many years. The introduction of new immunosuppression medications however, has provided the opportunity to minimize or avoid CNIs, which may reduce the occurrence of toxicity to the kidney.

detailed_description.textblock:
It is clear that minimizing the use of CNIs may be beneficial to some or all kidney transplant recipients. The purpose of this study is to determine whether minimization of these CNI drugs will improve patient survival rates and long-term kidney function.
If the subject agrees to participate in this research project, they will be randomly assigned to one of two different immunosuppression drug combinations. All of the drugs used in this study are standard FDA Approved immunosuppressive drugs currently in use by transplant patients. It is unclear however, which combination provides a better long-term outcome.
If after six months of being on the study the subject has not experienced a rejection episode that excludes them from participating in the second phase of this study, they will asked whether or not they would like to continue the study. If they decide to participate in Phase II, there will be another randomization to one of two different immunosuppression drug combinations. This will involve either being assigned to a group that will have their CNI dose lowered or a group that will have their CNI drug stopped and replaced with a non-CNI drug called Sirolimus. Phase II begins at 6 months post-transplant and a second consent will be obtained for those who participate in Phase II.

primary_outcome.measure: Phase I: The Minimization of Negative Side Effects - Patient Survival
primary_outcome.description: The percentage of patients alive at 6 month post transplant.

primary_outcome.measure: Phase II: The Minimization of Negative Side Effects - Patient Survival
primary_outcome.description: The percentage of patients alive at 7 years post transplant or at the end of study activities. Not all participants completed 7-year follow-up.

primary_outcome.measure: Phase I: The Minimization of Negative Side Effects - Graft Survival
primary_outcome.description: Percent of participants at 6 months with a functioning graft (without graft failure).

primary_outcome.measure: Phase II: The Minimization of Negative Side Effects - Graft Survival
primary_outcome.description: The percentage of patients with a functioning graft (without graft failure) at 7 years post transplant or at the end of study activities. Not all participants completed 7-year follow-up.
Percent of participants at 6 months without acute rejection.
The percentage of patients without acute rejection at 7 years post transplant or at the end of study activities. Not all participants completed 7-year follow-up.

intervention.description: Dose and frequency determined as usual by transplant physicians. The drugs are not experimental drugs. The study is looking at reducing negative side effects of some of the drugs.
intervention.other_name: CSA, Gengraf, Neoral, Sandimmune, MMF, Mycophenolate Mofetil

intervention.description: Dose and frequency determined as usual by transplant physicians. The drugs are not experimental drugs. The study is looking at reducing negative side effects of some of the drugs.

intervention.intervention_name: Low Dose CNI (Cyclosporine or FK) and Cellcept
intervention.description: Dose and frequency determined as usual by transplant physicians. The drugs are not experimental drugs. The study is looking at reducing negative side effects of some of the drugs.
intervention.other_name: Gengraf, Neoral, Sandimmune, Tacrolimus, Prograf, MMF

intervention.description: Dose and frequency determined as usual by transplant physicians. The drugs are not experimental drugs. The study is looking at reducing negative side effects of some of the drugs.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Kidney Transplant Recipients > 18 years old
- First or Second Kidney Transplant only
Exclusion Criteria:
- Kidney Transplant Recipients < 18 years old
- Kidney Transplant Recipients who have a history of > 2 kidney transplants
- Kidney Transplant Recipients with an already functioning non-renal transplant
- Kidney Transplant Recipients who receive another organ simultaneously at the same time of their kidney transplant (example: Kidney/pancreas, kidney/liver)
- Non-skin malignancy with 2 years previous to enrollment
- Donor Specific Antibodies to kidney donor

participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: All patients consented at time of transplant for phase 1. At 6 months post-transplant, patients were re-consented for phase 2. All patients represented for phase 2 were included for phase 1. Patients who were not re-consented for phase 2, were followed for 7 years under phase 1 protocol.

group.title: Phase I Arm 1
group.description: CSA and MMF Cyclosporine & Cellcept: Dose and frequency determined as usual by transplant physicians. The drugs are not experimental drugs. The study is looking at reducing negative side effects of some of the drugs.

group.title: Phase I Arm 2
group.description: FK and MMF Prograf & Cellcept: Dose and frequency determined as usual by transplant physicians. The drugs are not experimental drugs. The study is looking at reducing negative side effects of some of the drugs.

group.title: Phase II Arm 1
group.description: Low CNI and MMF Low Dose CNI (Cyclosporine or FK) and Cellcept: Dose and frequency determined as usual by transplant physicians. The drugs are not experimental drugs. The study is looking at reducing negative side effects of some of the drugs.

group.title: Phase II Arm 2
group.description: Rapa and MMF Rapamune and Cellcept: Dose and frequency determined as usual by transplant physicians. The drugs are not experimental drugs. The study is looking at reducing negative side effects of some of the drugs.

group.title: Arm1 (Phase 1 & 2)
group.description: Participants from Phase 1, Arm 1 (CSA and MMF) and participants from Phase 2, Arm 1 (Low CNI and MMF)

group.title: Arm 2 (Phase 1 & 2)
group.description: Participants from Phase 1, Arm 2 (FK and MMF) and participants from Phase 2, Arm 2 (Rapa and MMF)

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

measure.title: Age
measure.population: This study had a sequential enrollment. Not all of the participants from phase one moved on to phase two, which is why phase two has a smaller number of participants analyzed.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
